subject: Home & DIY
title: Why Your Water Heater Could Explode
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Why Your Water Heater Could Explode.

hook.text: A water heater without a working pressure relief valve is a bomb. MythBusters launched one through a two-story building.

buildup.text: Water heaters heat water in a sealed tank. As water heats, it expands and pressure builds continuously.

discovery.text: The temperature-pressure relief valve opens at 150 PSI or 210Â°F, releasing water before pressure goes critical.

twist.text: TPR valves corrode and stick closed over time. Homeowners are supposed to test them annually, but almost nobody does.

climax.text: If the thermostat fails and the TPR valve sticks, steam builds until the tank rupturesâ€”with explosive force.

punchline.text: One stuck valve turns hot water into a rocket.

quiz.question: What safety device prevents a water heater from exploding?
options: A pressure-reducing regulator on the supply line
